description: Hard - Scipio Africanus and Rome's Victory

questions.question: Who was Scipio and what made his appointment to command in Spain unusual militarily? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: He was an elderly experienced general with decades of military command experience
He was in his late 20s and the son of a general defeated by Hannibal at Trebia
He was a Greek mercenary commander hired specifically to defeat Carthaginian forces
He came from a merchant family and had no prior military experience or training
He was appointed despite his youth because Rome needed military talent and capability

questions.question: What were Scipio's major achievements during his Spanish military campaigns? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: He outmaneuvered Carthaginian forces and conducted a brilliant campaign throughout Spain
He captured the major Carthaginian stronghold of Carthago Nova militarily
He defeated Carthaginian armies and eliminated Carthaginian power in Spanish territories completely
He negotiated peace treaties with Carthage and ended the war prematurely
He created circumstances preventing Hannibal from receiving reinforcements from Spain

questions.question: What strategic significance did Scipio's victory of Hasdrubal in Spain have for the overall war? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: It eliminated Hannibal's primary source of reinforcements and support from Spanish territories
It demonstrated Rome could defeat Carthage and gave Romans confidence in eventual victory
It forced Carthage to negotiate immediate peace terms favorable to Rome completely
It proved that Rome's citizen armies were superior to Carthaginian mercenary forces entirely
It meant Hannibal would have to sustain his Italian campaign without Spanish military support

questions.question: What was Scipio's strategic response to Hannibal's superior tactical brilliance in Italy? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: He attempted to match Hannibal's tactics through conventional pitched battles and formations
He pursued an indirect strategy to strike at Carthage's power in other geographic theaters
He recognized Rome could not defeat Hannibal through traditional Mediterranean warfare
He focused exclusively on defending Italian territories from Carthaginian invasion and conquest
He decided to invade Carthage's homeland to threaten Carthage directly and force decisions

questions.question: What did Scipio's invasion of North Africa in 204 BCE force Carthage to do militarily? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Carthage could maintain Hannibal in Italy without diverting forces to Africa defensively
Carthage had to decide whether to continue supporting Hannibal or defend the homeland
Carthage eventually recalled Hannibal from Italy to defend North Africa against Scipio
Carthage evacuated Hannibal entirely and established a new military base in Egypt
Carthage surrendered immediately upon learning of Scipio's invasion without military resistance
questions.text_reference: Section 11: The Strategy to End the War

questions.question: What was the significance of Hannibal's recall from Italy after more than a decade of campaigning? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Hannibal left Italy in triumph having defeated all Roman military opposition successfully
Hannibal's departure from Italy ended the direct military threat to Rome's homeland
Roman forces were relieved of the pressure from Hannibal's tactical superiority militarily
It demonstrated Carthage prioritized defending the homeland over supporting Hannibal in Italy
The recall allowed Rome to consolidate control of Italy and prevent further Carthaginian expansion
Hannibal was recalled due to political factions within Carthage opposing his command

questions.question: What characterized the Battle of Zama (202 BCE) compared to earlier Carthaginian victories? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Scipio commanded Roman forces against Hannibal in a final major engagement decisively
It was a bitterly contested battle unlike Cannae's overwhelming Carthaginian tactical dominance
Scipio's strategic thinking and Rome's improved tactics gave Rome the military advantage
Hannibal achieved complete tactical dominance and destroyed the Roman military force entirely
The battle demonstrated that Hannibal could be defeated by an equally skilled commander
questions.text_reference: Section 11: The Battle of Zama (202 BCE)

questions.question: What were the major terms imposed on Carthage by the Treaty of Zama (201 BCE)? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Carthage ceded Iberian territories to Rome and lost control of Spanish colonial possessions
Carthage had to pay Rome an enormous war indemnity over an extended time period
Carthage's military power was severely restricted through naval and army size limitations
The Numidian kingdom was recognized as independent reducing Carthaginian African control
Carthage was required to cede all Mediterranean island territories to Rome immediately

questions.question: How did the Second Punic War transform Rome's position in the Mediterranean world? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Rome emerged as the undisputed dominant Mediterranean power after defeating Carthage
Rome had proven it could match any military challenge through institutional and tactical capacity
Rome demonstrated resilience by surviving catastrophic defeats and adapting strategically
Rome's victory ensured Carthage would never challenge Roman dominance again permanently
Rome had proven citizen-based military systems superior to mercenary-based Carthaginian forces
questions.text_reference: Section 12: The Significance of the Second Punic War

questions.question: What was Carthage's fate following the Second Punic War and what did this demonstrate? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Carthage survived as an independent state but was fundamentally weakened and diminished
Treaty restrictions and territorial loss ensured Carthaginian continued decline as a power
Carthage completely disappeared as a civilization and was destroyed after the Second War
Within 50 years Rome and Carthage went to war a third time in which Rome destroyed Carthage
Carthage's fate demonstrated Rome's determination to eliminate future threats to its dominance
Carthaginian economic recovery allowed them to rebuild military capacity within two decades
questions.text_reference: Section 12: The End of Carthage as a Power
